Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: SURFing the Interface between Chemistry and Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to The Scripps Research Institute, located in Jupiter, Florida, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2017- 2019. Research at the Scripps Florida integrates cutting edge bioscience research with the development of chemical tools to probe basic biological questions. Students can join several departments, Chemistry, Immunology, Molecular Medicine, Structural Biology, and Neuroscience, where they will find themselves working at the interface between chemistry and biology. The REU experience will provide a diverse group of students with mentored training in scientific research at a top graduate program, professional development opportunities focused around graduate school, including ethics training, and guided training in scientific presentation and writing. These efforts will culminate in a campus-wide poster competition. Participants can be rising Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors, and will be selected by participating faculty based on their academic record, letters of reference and a statement of purpose.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Scripps Florida, as an REU site focused on the biochemical sciences, provides students from diverse backgrounds access to internationally renowned research programs that will foster their interest in science, and provide them with the tools to be successful in graduate school and beyond. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences, or as peer-reviewed publications.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://education.scripps.edu/undergraduate/flreu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Katrin Karbstein at kkarbst@scripps.edu) or the program coordinator (Dr. Albarran-Zeckler at rzeckler@scripps.edu). This REU site is co-funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences), and the Division of Chemistry (Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The NSF award 1659594 ?SURFing the Interface between Chemistry and Biology? allowed 31 undergraduate students to experience a 10-week summer research program at The Scripps Research Institute in Jupiter, Florida, an internationally renowned leader in basic and translational science. Over three summers (2017-2019) our program combined a high-level research experience at the bench with professional development opportunities that are aimed to increase the students? preparation for graduate school, as well as the competitiveness of their application. Finally, group-building activities such as a paddle boarding/kayak trip, a nighttime excursion to watch nesting sea turtles, and Happy Hours with the Institute?s graduate students are used to build a cohort-experience.

The types of scientific projects that summer undergraduates have carried out vary widely, depending on the host laboratory, ranging from Neuroscience, over Immunology to Biochemistry, Structural Biology to Chemistry. In the last three years 29 labs have participated in our summer undergraduate programs (funded by NSF and internal sources), but all projects reflect the interdisciplinary thematic focus of research at the interface between chemistry and different areas of biology, which is a hallmark of The Scripps Research Institute. All students had independent projects, carried out under the direct supervision of a senior graduate student or postdoc, with the active involvement of the faculty mentor. Thus, the students had a realistic experience of the way that graduate research is conducted: independently, under the guide of a faculty mentor, and, typically growing from the project of a more senior lab member. Projects were designed to reflect the limited time and experience the students can bring to the project. The students gradually became more independent, taking ownership of their projects. Faculty members were actively involved in student mentoring, including the discussion of future plans, such as graduate school

In addition to measuring student learning in self-reported surveys, we have tracked the students? success and career choices. Of the students that have already graduated, 61% are now enrolled in Ph.D. programs in the biomedical or chemical sciences, many in the top schools around the country, including UC Berkeley, Harvard, Stanford, Scripps. 26% are working as research technicians with plans for graduate school, one is a science teacher. We are proud of these exceptional achievements of our mentees.

An additional measure of success in the research training goals are products, such as conference presentations, fellowships and publications co-authored by our students. 14 of the students have presented their work at national meetings, such as the ACS, ASBMB, ASCB, Society for Neuroscience, and Cold Spring Harbor meetings, as well as ABRCMS, and SACNAS. One won a prize. Furthermore, two of the fellows in the 2017-2019 cohort won NSF GRFP fellowships, two honorable mentions and one student received a McNair award. Finally, we can already report five peer-reviewed publications from the interns in this cohort.

Broader Impacts:

South Florida does not have a large number of research-intensive academic institutions. As a result, local students at all levels of education often find a limited number of role models for careers in science. The lack of role models and opportunities is even more of a concern for students from underserved communities. South Florida and the Southeastern United States are home to large populations of students underrepresented in the STEM fields, including Hispanic and African American students. Additionally, these areas also have large disparities in income and educational opportunities, which can limit the opportunities for low-income students of all ethnic backgrounds, who are often the first of their families to attend college.

We have targeted our recruitment efforts at these demographies (first-generation college students, racial minorities) to provide these neediest students with a meaningful research and career-development experience, which will strengthen not just their career prospects, but also substantially enhance the National STEM pipeline. In 2018 and 2019 80% of our participants were URM and the remaining 20% were first-generation college students. In 2017, 90% were URM or first-generation college students. 4 students were recruited locally, and 5 came from the Southeastern US.

This program is part of a larger educational outreach effort directed by Dr. Rosie Albarran-Zeckler, the co-director of this grant, which has been recognized by the Florida Department of Education, Florida Board of Governors, and the Florida State House of Representatives committee on STEM education. This program has several elements: (i) a summer program for local high school students funded partially by the Kenan Trust; (ii) a small undergraduate summer program for high school program alumni funded by the Kenan Trust; (iii) NSF-funded professional development workshops for science teachers; (iv) A Lending Library program, which allows teachers to borrow equipment for their classroom. (v) Hands-on lesson plans such as What Makes You ?You?- DNA Isolation, Drug Discovery, Model Organisms, Introduction to Science, The Basic You - An Introduction to Genetics, and Discovering the Brain and its Functions.
